channel.title: Npc? pI
channel.description: how do i make a npc give a completest cape once have max skilled? max skill on server is 125

item.title: Npc? pI
item.dc:creator: @runescape_sucks runescape sucks
item.description:
@runescape_sucks wrote:

beale:

Okay well he asked how to do something, and i showed him one way to do it THAT WORKS. In my opinion that is all that matters…

Agreeing with sk8r, just because something works, doesn’t mean it is the best way to do it. In fact, most of the time, in programming if something “just works”, it is usually badly written.

The point he is trying to make is that if he wanted to add another skill, say sailing, this loop would no longer include that skill. It would only include the 25 skills before it. This may seem arbitrary, but it’s better to be safe than sorry.

In common practice you don’t loop through an array by just guessing the size. A good reason for this is human error. Say if you did this

for(int skill = 0; skill < 15; skill++) { }
You would have an error that wouldn’t show up as an error in the code, but would definitely show up when it came to checking the skills.

However, if you only checked the length of the playerSkill array,

for(int skill = 0; skill < player.playerLvel.length; skill++) { }
If you were to mistype any part of the playerLevel part, it would show up as an error, and upon fixing it, it would still perform as needed.

Read full topic

item.title: Npc? pI
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

Apparently someone doesn’t know programming concepts.

There’s a million ways you can go about doing something, but the right way would be the most efficient, and in Java’s case, the most OOP.

Defining a random number into the for loop is not very OOP (Especially when looping over an array with a fixed length), and as I stated earlier, will make things annoying if/when making changes to the system.

Read full topic

@sk8rdude461 wrote:

Just because it works doesn’t mean it’s right.

And please, read what I said a bit more carefully:

sk8rdude461:

The reason why I say not to define some random number, is if/when they decide to add a 26th skill, or they decide that there’s gonna be 20 skills instead of 25. Who wants to go edit a questionable amount of for loops to do change 1 single number? No one.

item.title: Npc? pI
item.dc:creator: @beale beale
item.description:
@beale wrote:

[quote=“sk8rdude461, post:30, topic:551149”]Beale you keep handing him the answer… And the wrong one at that.

If you want to loop an entire array, why not set the max value of the loop to the arrays length, and not a value you’re guessing?

int someArray[] = new int[25]; // Example 1: for(int i = 0; i < someArray.length; i++) { System.out.println("The value of index " + i + " is " + someArray[i]); someArray[i] = 125;// Setting to 125 for the next loop example. } // Example 2: for(int value : someArray) { System.out.println("The value is " + value); }

The problem with example 2 is, you don’t have an index to work with. So if you were going to use the int in the for loop for another purpose, then you would go with example 1. However, in the case of OP, example 2 should work fine. Assuming all skills in his skill array are being used…

If they’re not, then OP can A) Use example 1, and ignore the indexes not being used; B) Use example 1 or two, and set the array size to how many skills he is using; C) Define the specific number like you did.

The reason why I say not to define some random number, is if/when they decide to add a 26th skill, or they decide that there’s gonna be 20 skills instead of 25. Who wants to go edit a questionable amount of for loops to do change 1 single number? No one.[/quote]
I would really love to know how that is the wrong answer when i just inserted into my server to check and it worked perfectly…

Read full topic

item.title: Npc? pI
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

Beale you keep handing him the answer… And the wrong one at that.

If you want to loop an entire array, why not set the max value of the loop to the arrays length, and not a value you’re guessing?

int someArray[] = new int[25]; // Example 1: for(int i = 0; i < someArray.length; i++) { System.out.println("The value of index " + i + " is " + someArray[i]); someArray[i] = 125;// Setting to 125 for the next loop example. } // Example 2: for(int value : someArray) { System.out.println("The value is " + value); }

The problem with example 2 is, you don’t have an index to work with. So if you were going to use the int in the for loop for another purpose, then you would go with example 1. However, in the case of OP, example 2 should work fine. Assuming all skills in his skill array are being used…

If they’re not, then OP can A) Use example 1, and ignore the indexes not being used; B) Use example 1 or two, and set the array size to how many skills he is using; C) Define the specific number like you did.

The reason why I say not to define some random number, is if/when they decide to add a 26th skill, or they decide that there’s gonna be 20 skills instead of 25. Who wants to go edit a questionable amount of for loops to do change 1 single number? No one.

Read full topic

item.title: Npc? pI
item.dc:creator: @beale beale
item.description:
@beale wrote:

[quote=“sk8rdude461, post:28, topic:551149”][quote author=starbeast199 link=topic=670065.msg4480740#msg4480740 date=1429492680]
no it just ends the conv and no cape in my inv
so the chat is basically useless without the npc giving the items
[/quote]
I can think of some reasons why that’d be the case.

  1. You didn’t compile the recent changes so the code does not see to give the items
  2. You put the if statement in the wrong case (Whether by accident or you had the wrong case id)
  3. pre-existing code prevents the statement from being reached. (This is not the same as the “unreachable statement” error)
  4. one of the stats is not 125.

To find out which is the root of the cause, do the following:
Add a trace line (Like I said earlier for the actionButtonId) to case 9157. Directly after the case starts. This will make sure the code is making it to the case.
Add another trace line to the start of the if statement, right after the {. This will make sure the code sees the if statement.
Add another after the for loop. That makes sure you have all the stats.
And add one last one after where it should give you the cape. That will ensure that all steps were completed… And the player “should” have it (Which would mean there’s a problem in your add item code…)

After all is said and done, compile and make sure it was successful.
When you click on the yes. About 5 lines should print to your console. 1 for the button id, and up to 4 lines for the statements we just added.[/quote]

I have realized the problem. Simple issue really, just edit your code like this: sorry i figured that your server had 25 skills.

} else if(c.dialogueAction == 121) {
	for (int i = 0; i < *amount of skills in your server*; i++) {
	if (c.playerLevel[i] != 125) {
        c.getPA().closeAllWindows();
		c.sendMessage("You need level 125 on every skill to use this command.");
	return;
		}
	}
	c.sendMessage("<img=2> Congratulations. You Earned a Max Cape and a Special Reward! <img=2>.");
	c.getItems().addItem(14022, 1);
	c.getItems().addItem(14035, 1);
}

the problem was that before, the client was checking for 25 skills, for (int i = 0; i < 25; i++) { just change the 25 to the amount of skills in your server, and then above c.sendMessage("You need level 125 on every skill to use this command."); add c.getPA().closeAllWindows(); - That just closes the dialogue if you do not have the proper requirements. That code should work. If not, I don’t know what to tell you

Read full topic

item.title: Npc? pI
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“starbeast199, post:27, topic:551149”]no it just ends the conv and no cape in my inv
so the chat is basically useless without the npc giving the items[/quote]
I can think of some reasons why that’d be the case.

  1. You didn’t compile the recent changes so the code does not see to give the items
  2. You put the if statement in the wrong case (Whether by accident or you had the wrong case id)
  3. pre-existing code prevents the statement from being reached. (This is not the same as the “unreachable statement” error)
  4. one of the stats is not 125.

To find out which is the root of the cause, do the following:
Add a trace line (Like I said earlier for the actionButtonId) to case 9157. Directly after the case starts. This will make sure the code is making it to the case.
Add another trace line to the start of the if statement, right after the {. This will make sure the code sees the if statement.
Add another after the for loop. That makes sure you have all the stats.
And add one last one after where it should give you the cape. That will ensure that all steps were completed… And the player “should” have it (Which would mean there’s a problem in your add item code…)

After all is said and done, compile and make sure it was successful.
When you click on the yes. About 5 lines should print to your console. 1 for the button id, and up to 4 lines for the statements we just added.

Read full topic

either that, or your actionId button is not 121. go into dialoguehandler.java and make sure that the actionId button is 121, and if it isnt, then change it to 121[/quote]

case 120: sendNpcChat4("Hello "+c.playerName+", my name is Max", "I can give you a max cape as long as", "you have 125 in all of your skills", "Do you qualify for a max cape?", c.talkingNpc, "Max"); c.nextChat = 121; break; case 121: sendOption2("Yes, i qualify, give me my cape", "No, I dont have the proper stats"); c.dialogueAction = 121; break;

You Earned a Max Cape and a Special Reward! <img=2>."); c.getItems().addItem(14022, 1); c.getItems().addItem(14035, 1); }

item.title: Npc? pI
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“starbeast199, post:17, topic:551149”]what do you mean by the button id???
this is the whole code

if(c.dialogueAction == 121) { for (int i = 0; i < 25; i++) { if (c.playerLevel[i] != 125) { c.sendMessage("You need level 125 on every skill to use this command."); return; } } c.sendMessage("<img=2> Congratulations. You Earned a Max Cape and a Special Reward! <img=2>."); c.getItems().addItem(14022, 1); c.getItems().addItem(14035, 1); }
in dialoguehandler the case number is 120 - 121[/quote]

While that may be the whole code, it doesn’t show why it is giving the unreachable statement error. you need to show the code that is before the code you added.

When I say the button ID, I’m talking about the case ID you used for your clicking buttons:

[quote=“starbeast199, post:11, topic:551149”]now the the npcs talks but it won’t go to the next step of the command

case 121: if(c.dialogueAction == 121) { for (int i = 0; i < 25; i++) { if (c.playerLevel[i] != 125) { c.sendMessage("You need level 125 on every skill to use this command."); return; } } c.sendMessage("<img=2> Congratulations. You Earned a Max Cape and a Special Reward! <img=2>."); c.getItems().addItem(14022, 1); c.getItems().addItem(14035, 1); } break;
i used this code in my clicking button but it doesn’t pop up
i didn’t know what case to put so i insert a random one [/quote]

The case ID will be the button ID of whatever button you press…
Like I said earlier:

[quote=“sk8rdude461, post:12, topic:551149”]I’m pretty sure the actionButtonId for the button you clicked is not 191.

You need to trace the button ID (Use System.out.println.) and then make the case for the id if it doesn’t exist. if it already exists, you just add onto the existing code.[/quote]

item.title: Npc? pI
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

Again, what is the button id?

Your current error is because you put the code somewhere where it will never be able to be executed.

Here is an example of the error

public static void main(String []args){ boolean aBool = true; return; if(aBool == true) { System.out.println("hi"); return; } }
Because the return statement is before the if statement, the if statement will never print out “hi” to the console, even though aBool is clearly true. Thus, why an unreachable statement error would show up if you try to compile this.

Also: You didn’t provide enough code to explain why you’re getting the error.

Read full topic

item.title: Npc? pI
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

What’s the button id?

If you used this code:

} else if(c.dialogueAction == 121) { for (int i = 0; i < 25; i++) { if (c.playerLevel[i] != 125) { c.sendMessage("You need level 125 on every skill to use this command."); return; } } c.sendMessage("<img=2> Congratulations. You Earned a Max Cape and a Special Reward! <img=2>."); c.getItems().addItem(*Max cape item id*, 1);
Without any modifications, I can see 3 different things you need to change for it to work:

  1. Remove the } before else if(c.
  2. It should be an if statement, not an else if.
  3. You’re missing the max cape ID.
